title: Daniel Geiszler
text:
This is a running list of etymologies that I think are neat. Keep in mind that not everything Iâ€™m presenting here have universal acceptance.
Temujin Genghis Khan was just a title; his real name was Temujin. Temujin is a Mongolic name that was probably borrowed from the Proto-Turkic *temÃ¼rÄi meaning â€œblacksmithâ€. The -ci suffix denotes a person who works with something, in this case *temÃ¼r, or iron. Modern Turkishâ€™s â€œdemirciâ€, also meaning â€œblacksmithâ€, is a descendent of this word and a cognate to Temujin. These names and their friends were and are still common throughout the region. For example, Timur (also known as Tamerlame), of the Timurid Empire, shares the same rootâ€”Timur, like Turkish demir, means iron.
Ordu is the Turkish word for â€œarmyâ€. It actually has an English cognate, â€œhordeâ€! Quite a few European languages seem to have picked this word up via contact with Central Asians. The most likely source appears to be Proto-Turkic, which makes sense given the role they played in Central Asian empires. But thereâ€™s another cognate to ordu thatâ€™s even more interesting: Urdu, the national language of Pakistan. The Mughal Empire of India established Persian as the official language of the empire, and the Hindustani dialect spoken in the military camps came to be referred to as â€œZaban-e-Urduâ€ in Persian, or â€œlanguage of the armyâ€, eventually being shortened to just â€œUrduâ€.
Rickshaws are small, hand-drawn passenger carts that were (and in some places, are) popular in Asia. It comes from the Japanese word äººåŠ›è»Š jinrikisha. But when it entered the English language, it actually already had a cognate, a word that came from the same root: wheel.
Five thousand years, a group called the Yamnaya used carts and wagons on the Ukrainian Steppe. This group is generally accepted to be the source of the Indo-European Languagesâ€”a language family encompassing languages as diverse as English, Persian, and Hindi. Their word for wheel was probably something like *kÊ·Ã©kÊ·los. This evolved over time to be something like *hwehwlÄ…, in Proto-Germanic, the most recent common ancestor of languages like German, English, and Norwegian. This eventually became _hweÅl_ in Old English and wheel today. That was journey that the word *kÊ·Ã©kÊ·los* took westward to arrive in English as wheel. But how did it arrive in Japanese as jinrikishaw?
Not all of the Yamnaya people went west into Europe. Some went south into Iran and India, others went east to the edge of Mongolia. We call the earliest of these people the Afanasievo Culture, but we only know them through their archeological remains. One of the things we know about them, however, is that they used carts as early as ~3500 BCE. They are also likely to be the source of a group known as the Tocharians, that lived in the Tarim Basin in modern day Xinjiang, China. They spoke a family of languages known as Tocharian and were producing manuscripts in their languages as late as 500-800 AD. Between the Afanasievans and the Tocharians, there was almost certainly a continuous, cart-using Indo-European presence on the Chinese periphery for roughly 4000 years, a time period including the earliest known presence of wheeled vehicles in China.
Some of these Indo-European speakers are likely the source of the Old Chinese word for wheeled vehicles, è»Š, which would have been pronounced _*kÊ°lja_ around 1200 BC. This evolved into something like _*tÍ¡É•Ê°ia_ in Middle Chinese. That was borrowed into Japanese as äººåŠ›è»Š jinrikisha, or â€œhuman-power cartâ€, recognizably the same word we use in English today and a cognate with â€œwheelâ€.
